Roles & Responsibilities
Roles & Responsibilities

Departmental Responsibilities: Compliance with state policies and reporting requirements Determining resource augmentation needs Prioritizing IT proposals & funding requests from a departmental & fund source perspective
Departmental
Responsibilities:
Compliance with state policies and
reporting requirements
Determining resource augmentation needs
Prioritizing IT proposals & funding
requests from a departmental & fund
source perspective

Departmental Responsibilities: Submitting prioritized IT proposals & funding requests to agency Responding to control agency questions in a timely manner Notifying DOIT of the project’s funding level as specified in the Budget Act
Departmental
Responsibilities:
Submitting prioritized IT proposals &
funding requests to agency
Responding to control agency questions in a
timely manner
Notifying DOIT of the project’s funding
level as specified in the Budget Act

Agency Responsibilities:
Agency Responsibilities:

Ensuring department proposals comply with agency strategies, goals, and policies Prioritizing IT proposals & funding requests from an agency-wide & fund source perspective Submitting prioritized proposals & funding requests to the DOIT
Ensuring department proposals comply with
agency strategies, goals, and policies
Prioritizing IT proposals & funding
requests from an agency-wide & fund
source perspective
Submitting prioritized proposals & funding
requests to the DOIT

DOIT’s Roles & Responsibilities:
DOIT’s Roles &
Responsibilities:

Advocate
Advocate

– Advancing the use of technology in making government more efficient
– Advancing the use of technology in – A d v a n c i n g
t h e
u s e
o f
t e c h n o l o g y
i n
making government more efficient

– Working with departments, agencies, and DOF in resolving fiscal issues concerning the deployment of IT
– Working with departments, agencies, and – W o r k i n g
w i t h
d e p a r t m e n t s ,
a g e n c i e s ,
a n d
DOF in resolving fiscal issues concerning
the deployment of IT

– Representing the Administration in
– Representing the Administration in – R e p r e s e n t i n g
t h e
A d m i n i s t r a t i o n
i n

legislative hearings and other events as they relate to IT activities
legislative hearings and other events as
they relate to IT activities

Gatekeeper
Gatekeeper

Ensuring efforts and resources are expended only on proposals that are properly aligned with the state’s overall IT strategies, infrastructure, and policies Conferring with the DOF to determine whether proposals are consistent with statewide budget priorities
Ensuring efforts and resources are
expended only on proposals that are
properly aligned with the state’s overall IT
strategies, infrastructure, and policies
Conferring with the DOF to determine
whether proposals are consistent with
statewide budget priorities

Control Agency Providing guidance to departments and agencies on IT proposals Reviewing IT proposals Denying IT proposals that are not aligned with state policies and strategies Granting final IT project approval (after the project has been funded at the level necessary for project success) Overseeing issues and concerns that are unique or special to IT projects
Control Agency
Providing guidance to departments and agencies on
IT proposals
Reviewing IT proposals
Denying IT proposals that are not aligned with
state policies and strategies
Granting final IT project approval (after the
project has been funded at the level necessary for
project success)
Overseeing issues and concerns that are unique or
special to IT projects

DOF Responsibilities:
DOF Responsibilities:

Reviewing proposals and funding requests Communicating with the DOIT and/or the department to clarify and resolve issues Incorporating supported proposals and funding requests into overall statewide funding priorities Notifying the DOIT and the department of its decision
Reviewing proposals and funding requests
Communicating with the DOIT and/or the
department to clarify and resolve issues
Incorporating supported proposals and
funding requests into overall statewide
funding priorities
Notifying the DOIT and the department of
its decision

New & Enhanced
Requirements

Preliminary Feasibility Study Report (Pre-FSR)
Preliminary Feasibility
Study Report
(Pre-FSR)

What is a Pre-FSR?
What is a Pre-FSR? W h a t
i s
a
P r e - F S R ?

A brief, conceptual project description:
A brief, conceptual project
description:

proposal concept justification high-level implementation plans anticipated funding source(s)
proposal concept
justification
high-level implementation plans
anticipated funding source(s)

Pre-FSR Objectives
Pre-FSR Objectives

Minimize investment in the development of a reportable FSR that has little chance of being approved
Minimize investment in the development of a
reportable FSR that has little chance of being
approved

Ensure focus is on technology initiatives to most effectively support mission critical programs
Ensure focus is on technology initiatives to most
effectively support mission critical programs

Ensure consistency of IT projects with departmental and statewide strategies, policies, and standards
Ensure consistency of IT projects with
departmental and statewide strategies, policies,
and standards

Pre-FSR Reporting Criteria
Pre-FSR Reporting Criteria

A Pre-FSR is not required if: – the proposed project is mandated by legislation,
A Pre-FSR is not required if:
– the proposed project is mandated by legislation, – t h e
p r o p o s e d
p r o j e c t
i s
m a n d a t e d
b y
l e g i s l a t i o n ,

or
or

– the proposed project will be entirely funded through a grant specific to the proposed activity
– the proposed project will be entirely funded – t h e
p r o p o s e d
p r o j e c t
w i l l
b e
e n t i r e l y
f u n d e d
through a grant specific to the proposed
activity

A Pre-FSR is required for proposed IT projects that meet one or more of the following criteria. . .
A Pre-FSR is required for proposed IT
projects that meet one or more of the
following criteria. . .

Pre-FSR Reporting Criteria
Pre-FSR Reporting Criteria

The estimated development schedule exceeds one year
The estimated development schedule exceeds one
year

The estimated total project costs exceed $1,000,000
The estimated total project costs exceed
$1,000,000

Involves Wide Area Network (WAN) facilities or services other than those acquired through Department of General Services or a State Consolidated Data Center (SCDC) and is over the
Involves Wide Area Network (WAN) facilities or
services other than those acquired through
Department of General Services or a State
Consolidated Data Center (SCDC) and is over the

department’s cost threshold
department’s cost threshold

Pre-FSR Reporting Criteria
Pre-FSR Reporting Criteria

Includes the use of new technologies not currently supported by the department or a SCDS and is over the department’s cost threshold
Includes the use of new technologies not currently
supported by the department or a SCDS and is
over the department’s cost threshold

Conflicts with the state’s enterprise systems strategy solution
Conflicts with the state’s enterprise systems
strategy solution

Feasibility Study Report (FSR)
Feasibility Study
Report (FSR)

What is an FSR?
What is an FSR? W h a t i s
a n
F S R ?

Complete summary of the results of a feasibility study conducted to address a problem or opportunity Establishes the business case for the investment of state resources A formal request to initiate a project The contract between the department, agency, the DOIT and DOF
Complete summary of the results of a
feasibility study conducted to address a
problem or opportunity
Establishes the business case for the
investment of state resources
A formal request to initiate a project
The contract between the department,
agency, the DOIT and DOF

FSR Objectives
FSR Objectives

Provide justification and priority of the project Demonstrate a viable and cost-effective solution consistent with statewide policies has been selected Demonstrate capability to ensure project success
Provide justification and priority of the
project
Demonstrate a viable and cost-effective
solution consistent with statewide policies
has been selected
Demonstrate capability to ensure project
success

FSR Reporting Criteria
FSR Reporting Criteria

Estimated total development and acquisition costs exceed the department’s cost threshold Required by mandate or subject to legislative review Involves a budget action
Estimated total development and
acquisition costs exceed the department’s
cost threshold
Required by mandate or subject to
legislative review
Involves a budget action

FSR Reporting Criteria
FSR Reporting Criteria

Involves acquisition of microcomputer commodities and the department does not have an approved Workgroup Computing Policy (WCP) Involves electronic access to private information by entities that do not “own” the data or whose access is not specifically authorized by law Involves WAN facilities or services other than those acquired through Department of General Services or a SCDC
Involves acquisition of microcomputer commodities
and the department does not have an approved
Workgroup Computing Policy (WCP)
Involves electronic access to private information
by entities that do not “own” the data or whose
access is not specifically authorized by law
Involves WAN facilities or services other than
those acquired through Department of General
Services or a SCDC

FSR Reporting Criteria
FSR Reporting Criteria

Involves technologies not currently supported by the department or a SCDC Involves activities defined in the DOIT’s Enterprise Systems Report Involves the acquisition or upgrade of a multi-user CPU (except for previously approved projects or office automation)
Involves technologies not currently supported by
the department or a SCDC
Involves activities defined in the DOIT’s
Enterprise Systems Report
Involves the acquisition or upgrade of a multi-user
CPU (except for previously approved projects or
office automation)

What is an FSR Reporting Exemption Request?
What is an FSR Reporting W h a t i s
a n
F S R
R e p o r t i n g
Exemption Request?

A request for an exemption from control agency reporting on a specific IT activity
A request for an exemption from
control agency reporting on a specific
IT activity

FSR Reporting Exemption Request Objectives
FSR Reporting Exemption
Request Objectives

Allows appropriate approval oversight authority to be determined
Allows appropriate approval oversight
authority to be determined

Allows appropriate documentation requirements to be determined
Allows appropriate documentation
requirements to be determined

Project Change Request (PCR)
Project Change
Request (PCR)

What is a PCR?
What is a PCR? W h a t i s
a
P C R ?

A formal request to proceed with the development of a Special Project Report that answer the following: – What change is being proposed? – Why is the change needed? – How will the change impact the project? – How will the change be incorporated?
A formal request to proceed with the development
of a Special Project Report that answer the
following:
– What change is being proposed? – W h a t
c h a n g e
i s
b e i n g
p r o p o s e d ?
– Why is the change needed? – W h y
i s
t h e
c h a n g e
n e e d e d ?
– How will the change impact the project? – H o w
w i l l
t h e
c h a n g e
i m p a c t
t h e
p r o j e c t ?
– How will the change be incorporated? – H o w
w i l l
t h e
c h a n g e
b e
i n c o r p o r a t e d ?

PCR Objectives
PCR Objectives

Provides the department and the DOIT with preliminary information needed to assess the merits of a proposed change before: – the change is implemented, and – resources are spent on the development of a
Provides the department and the DOIT
with preliminary information needed to
assess the merits of a proposed change
before:
– the change is implemented, and – t h e
c h a n g e
i s
i m p l e m e n t e d ,
a n d
– resources are spent on the development of a – r e s o u r c e s
a r e
s p e n t
o n
t h e
d e v e l o p m e n t
o f
a

Special Project Report that may not be accepted or approved
Special Project Report that may not be
accepted or approved

PCR Objectives
PCR Objectives

Provides an early opportunity for the DOIT to become involved in the decision making process Provides an opportunity for the department to receive DOIT direction and guidance when it will be most beneficial
Provides an early opportunity for the DOIT
to become involved in the decision making
process
Provides an opportunity for the
department to receive DOIT direction and
guidance when it will be most beneficial

PCR Reporting Criteria
PCR Reporting Criteria

If the project was not initially reportable and a proposed change would make the project reportable under the FSR Reporting Criteria, the department must follow the PCR process
If the project was not initially reportable
and a proposed change would make the
project reportable under the FSR
Reporting Criteria, the department must
follow the PCR process

PCR Reporting Criteria

If a project is reportable and the proposed change meets one or more of the following: – The project’s business objectives or

requirements are no longer valid because of a new mandate

Questions?

Special Project Report (SPR)
Special Project
Report (SPR)

What is an SPR?
What is an SPR? W h a t i s
a n
S P R ?

The mechanism used to submit detailed project change proposals to the DOIT for approval
The mechanism used to submit
detailed project change proposals to
the DOIT for approval

SPR Objectives
SPR Objectives

Allows the department, the DOIT, and the DOF to assess the merits of a proposed change Helps to ensure state IT projects are being rigorously controlled in a manner to ensure taxpayer dollars are being spent in a cost effective and efficient manner Allows the department, the DOIT, and the DOF to determine the continued viability of the project
Allows the department, the DOIT, and the DOF to
assess the merits of a proposed change
Helps to ensure state IT projects are being
rigorously controlled in a manner to ensure
taxpayer dollars are being spent in a cost
effective and efficient manner
Allows the department, the DOIT, and the DOF to
determine the continued viability of the project

SPR Reporting Criteria
SPR Reporting Criteria

If an approved project is funded at a different level than anticipated at approval, the department must consult with the DOIT to determine whether an SPR is required If a PCR for the proposed change has been approved
If an approved project is funded at a
different level than anticipated at
approval, the department must consult with
the DOIT to determine whether an SPR is
required
If a PCR for the proposed change has been
approved

SPR Documentation

Updated Project Summary Package
SPR, including updated EAWs

SPR Contents

needed)

Project Initiation & Approval Process
Project Initiation & Approval
Process

Effective 5/1/98 and for the FY 99/00 Budget Cycle
Effective 5/1/98 and for the FY
99/00 Budget Cycle

Features of the new PIA Process
Features of the new PIA
Process

Sequential DOIT review timeframes Prioritization Control agency involvement earlier in the process More opportunities for the control agency to provide direction and guidance New roles & responsibilities New or enhanced documentation requirements New or revised reporting criteria
Sequential
DOIT review timeframes
Prioritization
Control agency involvement earlier in the process
More opportunities for the control agency to
provide direction and guidance
New roles & responsibilities

New or revised reporting criteria
